TutoiralLogic Logic
TutoiralLogicDescription Enhance your understanding of basic logic systems.
TutoiralLogicSubTitle Practical Training: Stage IV
IntoTutoiralLogicDescription Welcome back, Cadet. Stationeer Command wants to be sure that you understand basic logic circuit design. Demonstrate your grasp of the fundamentals by designing a lighting control system.
8Narration0D Like most logic systems in the galaxy, Stationeers devices use two values: 0 and 1, to set states like 'on/off', 'open/close' and 'lock/unlock'. Today, you will use logic systems to set the 'on/off' value on a light. Start by placing a light switch (lever).
8ConstructLever Place lever in highlighted position
8Narration1D Most ODA devices have two ports: power and data. Data ports transmit information about a device's current state, using the same network as power. So connect your switch to the cable network.
8ConstructCable Place cable in highlighted position.
8ConstructCable2 Connect data port on switch to cable network
8Narration2D Like its name suggests, a logic reader reads logic values from devices. To read data from the switch, place a logic reader in the highlighted position. Note that logic flows in one direction only.
8ConstructReader Place logic reader in highlighted position
8Narration3D A logic writer recieves a value from the logic reader, then writes that value to a given device - a light, in this case. Simple.
8ConstructWriter Place logic writer in highlighted position
8Narration4D Now it's time to program your logic devices, starting with the logic reader. Use a screwdriver to set the input (IN) to 'Lever'. Then set the variable (VAR) to 'Open', so the reader knows what to look for.
8LogicReaderLogicInput1 Set logic reader input (IN) to 'Lever'
8LogicReaderLogic1 Set logic reader variable (VAR) to 'Open'
8Narration5D Now program your logic writer. First, set its input (IN) to 'Logic reader'. Then set the output (OUT) to 'Wall Light'. Lastly, to turn the light 'on', set the output variable (OUT VAR) to 'On'.
8LogicWritterInput1 Set logic writer input (IN) to 'Logic reader'
LogicWritterOutput1 Set logic writer output (OUT) to 'Wall Light' >
8LogicWritterLogic1 Set output variable (OUT VAR) to 'On'
8Narration6D Now that the logic reader and the logic writer are programmed, it's safe to turn them on.
8TurnOnReader Turn on logic reader
8TurnOnWriter Turn on logic writer
8Narration7D Excellent - now you're ready to test the logic circuit. Try turning on the light by flipping the lever.
8TurnOnWallLight Use logic switch to turn on light
8Narration8D Well done, Cadet - you've created your first logic circuit. Now, let's look at how to control several devices at once. First, connect all of the lights in the room to the logic network.
8ConstructCable2 Complete logic cable network for lights
8Narration9D You'll need to adjust the logic devices you've just programmed. Make sure you turn them off first, or things get messy.
8TurnOffWriter Turn off logic writer
8TurnOffReader Turn off logic reader
8Narration10D Because you've turned off the logic writer, you can reset the logic switch without turning off your lights and throwing yourself into terrifying darkness.
8Closelever Reset logic switch.
8Narration11D Batch writers are just like logic writers, except they can writer to multiple devices at once. You'll need to add a batch writer to the network.
8ConstructBatchWriter Place batch writer in highlighted position
8Narration12D Search through the batch writer's outputs for 'Wall Light'. This will cause it to write to every wall light on the network
8BatchWriterOutput Set batch writer output (OUT TYPE) to 'Wall Light'
8Narration13D Now set the batch writer's input (IN) to 'logic reader', and the variable it sets as 'On'.
8BatchWriterInput Set batch writer input (IN) to 'Logic reader'
8BatchWriterLogicType Set output variable (OUT VAR) to 'On'.
8Narration14D The batch writer is now programmed. So you're ready to turn it on, and the logic reader.
8TurnOnBatchWriter Turn on batch writer
8Narration15D Okay, let's test the whole system now - throw the lever and let there be light!
8TurnOnWallLight Turn on the lights
8Narration16D Great work, Cadet - you've mastered basic logic. But to press the important blue button and transmit your results, you need to get out of this room. The doors are locked. Let's use logic to fix that. First, turn off the logic units.
8TurnOffBatchWriter Turn off batch writer
8Narration17D You can now reset the logic switch without turning off your lights.
8Closelever Reset logic switch
8Narration18D Programing the door is simple. It's already connected to the network - so just set the original logic writer to output to 'Glass Door', and write to the door's 'Open' variable.
8BatchWriterOutput2 Set logic writer output (OUT) to 'Glass Door'
8BatchWriterLogicType2 Set logic writer variable (OUT VAR) to 'Open'
8Narration19D Now open the door using the logic switch.
8OpenDoor Use logic switch to open door
8Narration20D Excellent, Cadet. You now have the knowledge and skills to create basic logic circuits. Take your new wisdom, and experiment with other devices, systems and networks. There's a universe of possiblities out there. Press the important blue button to transmit your results to the ODA.
TutoiralLogicCompleteTutorial This confirms that the aforementioned Stationeer Cadet has satisfactorily demonstrated adequate skills and knowledge with basic logic systems.
